What are we doing to make sure that no adult will ever be placed in a setting or facility in which there are children? There is a huge difference between age verification and age estimation. What are we doing to protect children?
The Minister does not need to answer that. It is not on the topic of child poverty.

I will not go into any great detail. The matter was referenced in relation Tusla, and Tusla falls within my remit. When an individual is presented as being a young person seeking international protection, a referral, in terms of age, appropriateness and suitability, is made and then a determination is made by the Department of justice. I was just making that point because the matter was raised in relation to Tusla.

I am aware of the matter the Senator raised, which has been raised previously. Work is underway in the Department of justice to ensure that there is a stronger verification process in terms of the individuals who are referred to Tusla.
Will that be biometric in nature? Will it be AI driven? How will it be-----
I am not going to speak on behalf of another Department. It would not be appropriate to do so.
Can we go back to the topic of child poverty?
What we have to consider here are the children who may be placed in a setting with an adult and the vulnerable position they find themselves in.

I understand that, and I accept the Senator's bona fides in raising the matter. It would be inappropriate for me to comment on what another Department is doing. However, it is my understanding that work on a stronger mechanism or method of confirming age is under way within the Department of justice.
Is the Minister working in collaboration with that Department?
It is within the remit-----
Obviously, this matter relates to her Department.
Will the Senator respect my direction return to the questions on child poverty, the topic on our agenda for today?
All the questions have been already answered in relation to poverty, timelines, funding and everything else. That is fine. I thank the Minister very much.

I was attending a meeting of the education committee and saw the topic being discussed here, so I thought I would pop in for a minute. As the Minister knows, I have worked in the school completion programme for decades. Over the course of my career, poverty is something that sadly has not gone away. No matter what we seem to put in place, poverty has an effect on young people year on year. I am a TD for Dublin South-Central. There is a significant amount of poverty in the constituency. There is an impact on people there in the context of housing, the ability to access services and waiting lists that are miles long.

A previous speaker referred to Traveller accommodation. Labre Park in my constituency has been waiting for 25 years to be fully functioning and redeveloped. The project in that regard remains stalled. The Minister stated that Departments and the councils have drawn down the money, but Labre Park has still not been redeveloped. When people are living in dire housing conditions, it seriously affects their ability to thrive in their communities.

The Minister is working really hard on this but I was so disheartened when the budget was announced and it was stated that the Government will reduce the number of children living in poverty to a particular percentage. I was disappointed that a target was even mentioned. The target should be zero. I accept that it probably unrealistic, but we should not accept that a target of anything above zero is acceptable.

For those involved in youth work, the school completion programme or community development, this is a hard time of year. Organisations around the country are getting together with food banks to provide food packages for Christmas. Vouchers and Christmas presents are being bought for people. The Society of St. Vincent de Paul said it is going to spend tens of millions of euro this year to support families. That is heartbreaking. At a time when the country is so rich, I am flabbergasted that there is such a huge divide between what we have overall and the reality that exists on the ground. In that context, I refer to going into a house that is cold and mouldy. The children there might have a uniform and just one other set of clothes. That is it. I have been in homes where there is no food in the cupboards. There is nothing, and it is cold. Years ago, a mother froze to death in one of the flats in the area that I was working in. I would love to be able to say that this will not happen again, but it will. Christmas is a miserable time for so many people. Families living in poverty often have to borrow from people we would not recommend that they borrow from, particularly in view of the huge amounts of money they have to pay back afterwards and the fact that this will leave them in even greater debt.

From the Department's perspective, how long will it be until the target of zero is reached? Does the Minister think it is unrealistic of me to want that and to be able to say that in a country as rich as ours, there should be no poverty? I want people to have hope. At this time of year, it is very difficult for people in my constituency and for the families I have worked with over the decades. It is not just at this time of year, but it is particularly at this time of year. How far away are we from having zero poverty? What metrics can we put in place that will perhaps allow us to reach 0% during the lifetime of the Government? The Government stated that it is going to reduce the rate of poverty to 3% over the next five years. It currently stands at 5%. When will we get to 0%? What is being put in place to facilitate that?

I appreciate the experience the Deputy brings to the table in respect of this matter from an education point of view and from the point of view of her constituency. Within my Department and across government, the overall aim is to give the maximum opportunity to a child in life to succeed to their maximum potential. In the context of the issues the Deputy raised, whether in terms of housing, social welfare or whatever, that we that we have the unit with the Department of the Taoiseach that is dedicated to eliminating child poverty. This is a cross-government issue. There is no single Department under the remit of which all of these issues fall. Everybody has to play their part.

Every day is a challenge. However, Christmas is a particularly challenging time. Double social welfare payments and other measures have been announced. Notwithstanding that, there are huge challenges for people. We referenced the allocation going to the local authorities in terms of housing. I do not know the specifics of that in the context of the Deputy's area. Something we did not see before is that the housing allocation funding for each of the local authorities across the State for the period 2020 to this year have been fully drawn down.
That is a positive step forward.

In terms of my own Department, I can only speak to what we are doing and the efforts we are making around child poverty and providing equality of opportunity for children. From that point of view, we can say that more than 286,000 children benefit from the national childcare scheme so as to ensure that they can access early learning and childcare opportunities. We can also say that we have more than 105,000 children who are gaining free access to the ECCE programme. I made the point earlier that 70% of low-income families have said they would never have been in a position for their child to experience the ECCE programme if they was not free. We have introduced the equal start model, benefiting 37,000 children at this point, and there will be more going forward. The Deputy mentioned food as well. It is for that reason that we have introduced the bia blasta programme. We will do more in this space going forward.

My questions are next. I will return to the community and voluntary organisations, a number of which have appeared before the committee. I have also met a number of them, including Barnardos. There is such amazing work being done on the ground, but I am conscious that it is quite fragmented. One county might have a family resource centre, a Barnardos service and an active Society of St. Vincent de Paul, which is another one of the organisations that appeared before the committee, while another county, town or village may not have that level of support. I know the Department is conducting a mapping of parenting support services, with a view to producing a geospatial map. Is it planned to map where the food banks, clothes banks, counselling services, parenting support services and childcare services are located? Is there a sense of what community and voluntary organisations are in place, where they are and what supports they are providing? We know that Tusla is referring to community and voluntary organisations. We have to understand if there are gaps in some areas.

The Cathaoirleach made the point about Tusla referring to different organisations. They are being funded via Tusla to do the work. I said earlier that the financial resource is not the challenge in many instances. It is a challenge oftentimes, but in many instances it is not the primary concern. The Cathaoirleach will note that family resource centres are doing 101 different things. Some of them are contracted by Tusla to provide a counselling service. There are early learning services and parenting supports being run out of them. All of these organisations are being supported and funded to do that work. In terms of the newer family resource centres, they will come on stream on the basis of where there is a need and a gap in the service.
I am sorry to cut across the Minister. Barnardos told me about the fantastic home support it provides when it goes into homes and the relationships it builds up.
It is an excellent organisation.

In the committee, we heard about different examples of fantastic work being done all over the country. I know there will be ten additional resource centres, but do we have a sense of where there are gaps in the country? I know Tusla is funding those community voluntary organisations, and it is fantastic where they are in place, but, for example, Barnardos does not have centres in Mayo or Donegal. We know where there are no family resource centres, but do we have a sense of where there is a full gap?

In the first instance, we have a map of our childcare services. I know it is of particular interest to this committee. That will inform the work of our forward planning unit in deciding, where there is a gap, that the new model of practice may be suitable in that particular area. The childcare services are being mapped. The family resource centres are being mapped in terms of where we have a sufficiency or do not have a sufficiency, and also where the level of deprivation is greater and there is not a service available. We are mapping what is there so as to inform our knowledge of what is not there, as it were, going forward. It is those gaps that-----
There is probably still a slight gap around the likes of food banks and organisations that are providing one-to-one parenting support.

Much of the parenting support, to be fair, is on the basis of Tusla referral or the HSE. Again, it is funded through my Department. Excellent work is being done on the ground with these parenting groups. Many of their members come from a background of public health nursing and so on.
The social inclusion and community activation programme, SICAP, is doing that as well.

Yes. The work being done there is very impressive. Again, it seeks to mitigate the fact that some people do not have extended family supports. Some families who have moved to new areas may not have the extended family they normally would have had. There is a variety of different agencies stepping in to provide the resources, and they are funded to step in. I hear the larger point the Cathaoirleach is making as well.

That is where I see such great work being done. I sound like I am from Donegal but I am not. We often hear that Donegal is left behind in so many different ways. It struck me when Barnardos was here that there is no Barnardos organisation in Donegal.

I will move to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, UNCRC. In October, I attended the ombudsman's event for children, scouting organisations and different groups. They were looking for clearer timelines on when the UNCRC will be fully implemented. I can see from the Minister's brief that the Department is reviewing the findings of the review done by the committee and, as regards the second optional protocol, it is engaging with the Attorney General. Are there any clear timelines for the full implementation of the UNCRC and the second optional protocol?

That is an absolute priority. Obviously, everything we do is on foot of the advices we receive. There are often legal implications in this country that might not be a consideration elsewhere. We are very cognisant of that. It is a priority to do that as speedily as possible.
Not to push the issue, but the optional protocol was signed in 2000, 25 years ago.
There have been a number of reports subsequent to that. In the main, the reporting has been positive, from an Irish point of view.
I cannot push the Minister for a clear timeline but just to push it a little bit, maybe it will happen in the lifetime of this Government.
There you go.

Hard-to-reach communities and families were discussed. I thought Deputy Jen Cummins's contribution was very good. She reminded me of something. My father was a principal years ago and he often mentioned cases where a teacher would have been worried about a kid not having a pencil when that kid had not had a breakfast. We can all imagine the impact that poverty has. It is very important that the mapping happens and we have these facilities. It is not just about resources but also about having specialist public health nurses, making sure there are enough staff to make all the necessary referrals and that the service is provided and finding the gaps so that they can be provided.

We need to do some sort of chase on the specialist public health nurses. The piece in relation to mapping is all right. It is about putting a strategy together. Mr. Gerry Hone and Ms Kate Duggan both spoke about a new model of care to deal with complex cases. Some of the issues relate to hard-to-reach communities where there is not necessarily a history of continuing with education and, in some cases, employment. Beyond that, some of them have huge issues of intergenerational trauma, poverty and an element of dysfunction. Where early interventions have happened, we have seen that huge changes can happen and we do not need to use the nuclear option, which sometimes comes too late.
How can we put a strategy together? Will the Minister address the idea of a new model of care for dealing with complex cases and hard-to-reach communities, the really difficult pieces?
The Deputy referenced his dad. I have always felt we owe huge debt of gratitude to schools on the ground because they are the first point of contact for many families.
They are sometimes the best place to actually offer services.

Yes, I would never disagree on that one. What we are seeking to achieve in early learning, because it will be an earlier point of contact, will be a similar type of experience. We are making strides there. The Deputy referred to 20 years ago and how the principal or staff of a school might be worried about a child not having access to a pencil or food. We have come a long way from there. With the free books scheme and the hot school meals programme, every child is the same in the classroom. We are seeking to replicate that at an earlier point for children through what is being done in the Department in terms of early years, with the equal start and bia blásta programmes.

I hear the point the Deputy is making about hard-to-reach communities as well. I referred earlier to specific work being done to support communities. For example, education community development workers are working in ten locations specifically with Traveller and Roma communities and there are parenting support groups. I am a big believer in parenting support. If we can get it right for the parents, we will get it right for the next generation. Parenting supports are being provided across 17 Tusla areas for Traveller and Roma families. As I said, other parenting supports are being provided as well.

Regarding Tusla, its workers have spoken very openly to the committee about children and young people who have very specific challenges. We need to look at support for children in the broadest terms. In terms of special care support, I would love that this would not always have to be the case and that there could be a different type of intermediary support that would work with different Departments. The Department of justice is really proactive in engaging with us on youth diversion programmes, for all of the different challenges that young people meet in their day-to-day living. That is an example of the cross-departmental element.

The Minister spoke about the importance of play and recreation to children's and youths' development. In November 2020, I suggested to the then Minister, Deputy Roderic O'Gorman, introducing a €200 recreational voucher for all second level students. This could be used for club membership, gym membership, music or any other recreational activity for a child. Last year, 65,000 students did the leaving certificate and applied leaving certificate. I think that voucher might be a good investment to keep our children occupied and keep them socialising. It is not a lot of money, €200 euro per child. It would help parents out greatly in relation to the cost of activities and the pressures put on parents to provide those. Many parents can afford these activities but many others cannot. We all know that they live among us as well. I estimate that it would cost about €14 million, but it might be a little bit more. I ask the Minister to consider it for the budget next year.

We are open to looking at a variety of different measures. We mentioned, as the Deputy said, play and the opportunity for the maximum number of children to avail of play and that it would be inclusive. That is the emphasis in my Department. Whether it is playgrounds or multi-use game areas for older teenagers, or whatever the case might be, the main thing is that they would be inclusive. I will take on board the Senator's suggestion about the €200 voucher.

I think that is the average cost of gym membership for a child. It is about that where I am from but I do not know about Dublin. I also think gyms have a duty because young people will become their customers down the line, so they also have a duty to look after them. It takes a village to raise a child. All those who would avail of this voucher should look fairly on the young people that are coming with these vouchers and make those services available for that price.
I thank the Senator. I cannot say that it will be possible but I appreciate the suggestion.

I thank the Minister and her officials for appearing before the committee. It has been a really informative engagement. This topic is an important one every day of the week but this close to Christmas, when we are all seeing the supposed magic of Christmas on our televisions, we know there are stark differences between families. It is important that we are focused on this issue and are all working towards solving child poverty and deprivation. I thank everyone for their informative engagement on this subject.

debateSection.summary: The joint committee adjourned at 11.36 a.m. until 9.30 a.m. on Thursday, 18 December 2025.
